Debt Snowball Calculator

Create a personalized debt payoff plan using the snowball or avalanche method.

Your Debts

Amount you can pay beyond minimum payments

Understanding Debt Payoff Strategies

Getting out of debt requires a solid plan. The debt snowball and debt avalanche methods are two proven approaches to eliminate debt efficiently.

Debt Snowball Method

  • How it works: Pay minimums on all debts, then put extra money toward the smallest balance first
  • Advantage: Quick wins keep you motivated as you eliminate entire debts
  • Best for: People who need psychological encouragement to stay on track
  • Example: Pay off a $500 medical bill before a $2,000 credit card

Debt Avalanche Method

  • How it works: Pay minimums on all debts, then put extra money toward the highest interest rate debt first
  • Advantage: Saves you the most money in interest payments
  • Best for: People motivated by math and saving money
  • Example: Pay off a 20% APR credit card before a 5% student loan

Key Benefits of Becoming Debt-Free

Financial Freedom

More money available for savings, investments, and life goals

Reduced Stress

Eliminate the mental burden of owing money

Improved Credit

Lower credit utilization raises your credit score

Better Opportunities

Qualify for better rates on mortgages and loans

Debt Payoff Tips

  • Track spending to find extra money for debt payments
  • Negotiate rates - call creditors to ask for lower interest
  • Consider balance transfers to 0% APR cards (if disciplined)
  • Celebrate milestones to stay motivated
  • Automate payments to avoid missed payments
  • Increase income with side gigs to pay debt faster

Debt Payoff vs. Investing

ConsiderationPay Debt FirstInvest First
When it makes senseHigh interest debt (greater than 6-8%)Low interest debt (less than 4-5%)
Risk LevelGuaranteed "return" (interest saved)Market risk but potential growth
Best ForThose with high-interest consumer debtThose with low-rate mortgages/student loans

Common Debt Payoff Mistakes

  • Not changing spending habits - continuing to accumulate new debt
  • Paying randomly - without a clear strategy
  • Ignoring small debts - which can be quick wins
  • Not tracking progress - leading to loss of motivation
  • Giving up too soon - debt payoff is a marathon, not a sprint
